Question:
When performing wall walking, what is the initial position before leaning backwards?
A) Sitting on the floor
B) Standing with one's back to the wall
C) Lying face up on the floor
D) In a handstand position

During wall walking, how does one make contact with the wall?
A) By pressing the back against the wall
B) By pressing one's palms into the wall from the front
C) By pressing one's palms into the wall from behind
D) By pressing the feet into the wall

To increase the difficulty of the wall walking exercise, what additional movement can be performed?
A) "Walking" with the feet along the wall
B) "Walking" with the hands along the wall all the way back up again
C) Jumping off the wall with the legs
D) Performing a somersault away from the wall

In rope climbing competitions, what is the diameter of the natural fiber rope used?
A) 25 mm
B) 38 mm
C) 42 mm
D) 50 mm

What action has been taken against attempts to bolt routes at Clogwyn Du'r Arddu, such as Indian Face?
A) Encouragement of bolting for safety
B) Installation of additional bolts for difficult routes
C) Bolts have been added to improve route safety
D) Bolts have been removed to preserve the traditional climbing approach

Who made the historic first free ascent of Realization/Biographie, as documented in Dosage Volume I?
A) Jerry Moffatt
B) Ben Moon
C) Chris Sharma
D) Adam Ondra

Who is the American sport climbing pioneer who recounted the opposition of traditional climbers to both bolts and redpointing techniques?
A) Patrick Edlinger
B) Wolfgang Güllich
C) Alan Watts
D) Jerry Moffatt

What distinguishes sport climbing from free solo climbing?
A) The use of a belayer
B) The lack of any climbing protection
C) The use of pre-drilled bolts for protection
D) The requirement to climb in pairs

Approximately how many years is the expected lifespan of the highest quality stainless steel bolts used in sport climbing?
A) 10—15 years
B) 20—25 years
C) 30—35 years
D) 40—45 years

Which type of bolts have a shorter lifespan than the highest quality stainless steel bolts?
A) Titanium bolts
B) Cheaper plated stainless steel bolts
C) Carbon fiber bolts
D) Aluminum bolts

In sport climbing, why are routes graded solely for their technical difficulty?
A) Because the risk is eliminated by using bolts
B) Because it is based on the climber's experience
C) Because the weather affects the grading
D) Because of the type of climbing gear used

What does the grading of sport climbing routes NOT take into account?
A) The physical movements to ascend the route
B) The type of equipment used
C) The risk factor
D) The climber's personal style

The Australian system for grading sport climbing routes is also known as the _______ system.
A) French
B) American
C) UIAA
D) Ewbank

In sport climbing, what is the main purpose of using quickdraws when clipping the rope into the bolts?
A) To generate friction
B) To avoid rope drag
C) To measure the length of the route
D) To secure the belay device

Which of the following is NOT a standard piece of equipment required for lead climbing in sport climbing?
A) Harness
B) Quickdraws
C) Belay device
D) Traditional camming devices

On complex sport climbing routes, why is the alignment and length of quickdraws important?
A) To make the climb more challenging
B) To reduce the weight of the equipment
C) To avoid rope drag and ensure smooth climbing
D) To increase the friction for better grip

What term is used in sport climbing to describe a first free ascent where the climber ascends the route without falling or resting on the gear, but the quickdraws are pre-attached to the bolts?
A) Hangdogging
B) Headpointing
C) Pinkpointing
D) Redpointing

In sport climbing, which technique has become the standard definition of a first free ascent (FFA) across all climbing disciplines?
A) Hangdogging
B) Headpointing
C) Pinkpointing
D) Redpointing

Which climbing area in Spain is known for being fully bolted?
A) Montserrat
B) Siurana
C) Oliana
D) El Chorro

Which climber dominated female sport climbing in the late 1990s and early 2000s?
A) Lynn Hill
B) Catherine Destivelle
C) Josune Bereziartu
D) Angela Eiter

Which climber was among the first to compete in climbing competitions and set new female grade milestones in the 1980s?
A) Lynn Hill
B) Catherine Destivelle
C) Josune Bereziartu
D) Laura Rogora

Who took on the mantle of the world's strongest sport climber from Chris Sharma?
A) Adam Ondra
B) Wolfgang Güllich
C) Angela Eiter
D) Lynn Hill

What was the highest female sport climbing route grade achieved by 2017?
A) 9a (5.14d)
B) 9a+ (5.15a)
C) 9b (5.15b)
D) 9b+ (5.15c)

What is the title of the 2019 documentary film that explores the emergence of sport climbing in Britain during the 1980s?
A) Statement of Youth
B) Reel Rock 7
C) Dosage Volume I
D) The Climbing Revolution

By the early 1980s, leading rock climbers were reaching the limits of traditional climbing protection devices and looked to climb ________ rock faces.
A) blanker-looking
B) crack-filled
C) fissure-rich
D) boulder-strewn

What is the name of the route in Buoux that became an early example of a sport climbing route?
A) Chain Reaction 5.12c
B) Watts Tot 5.12b
C) Pichenbule 7b+
D) Redpoint Revolution

The practice of "redpointing" was controversial among traditional climbers for its technique of ________.
A) using advanced gear
B) climbing without ropes
C) practicing new routes before the first free ascent
D) avoiding the use of bolts

Sport climbing routes are known for being a purely sporting endeavor without the risks associated with ________.
A) indoor climbing
B) traditional climbing
C) competitive climbing
D) speed climbing

The bolting controversy in sport climbing was related to the protection of climbers on ________ rock surfaces.
A) indoor
B) artificial
C) natural
D) underwater

In which decade did competition climbing experience rapid development due to the safer aspect of sport climbing?
A) 1970s
B) 1980s
C) 1990s
D) 2000s

The 1988 International Sport Climbing Championship was significant for:
A) Introducing a new scoring system
B) The first use of bolted routes in competitions
C) Bringing together leading European and American climbers
D) Launching the first IFSC Climbing World Cup

Which organization was responsible for regulating major international climbing competitions by the end of the 1990s?
A) The International Olympic Committee (IOC)
B) The International Federation of Sport Climbing (IFSC)
C) The Union Internationale des Associations d'Alpinisme (UIAA)
D) Both B and C

The IFSC Climbing World Championships are held:
A) Annually
B) Biennially
C) Every four years
D) Every five years

Competitive climbing includes which of the following disciplines?
A) Sport climbing only
B) Bouldering only
C) Speed climbing only
D) Sport climbing, bouldering, and speed climbing

Advanced sport climbing routes often describe the hardest moves using which grading systems?
A) French "Font" and American "V-scale"
B) UIAA and British
C) Australian and Brazilian
D) Yosemite Decimal System and Ewbank

What is the main difference between French sport-grades and French "Font" boulder grades?
A) The numerical value
B) The type of climbing
C) The use of "capitalized" letters
D) The geographic location

What was the sport-grade of Silence, the route redpointed by Adam Ondra in 2017?
A) 9b
B) 9c
C) 9a+
D) 9b+

In the American grading system, what is the equivalent of a 9c French sport-grade?
A) 5.14d
B) 5.15a
C) 5.15c
D) 5.15d

According to the content, what is the purpose of using bouldering grades in sport climbing routes?
A) To describe the easiest moves
B) To provide a route name
C) To describe the hardest moves
D) To indicate the length of the route

The practice of bolting routes for sport climbing originated in the early _______.
A) 1970s
B) 1980s
C) 1990s
D) 2000s

One of the ethical debates in climbing centers around _______.
A) the use of climbing shoes
B) bolting natural rock faces
C) the type of clothing climbers wear
D) the use of chalk to improve grip

The inclusion of sport climbing in the Olympic Games occurred in the year _______.
A) 2016
B) 2018
C) 2020
D) 2022

In competition climbing, the discipline that incorporates the bolted sport climbing element is known as _______.
A) bouldering
B) lead climbing
C) speed climbing
D) free soloing

In sport climbing, what is the role of the second climber?
A) To lead and clip into pre-drilled bolts
B) To remove the quickdraws as they climb
C) To put in temporary protection equipment
D) To climb without any protection

What does the lead climber use to clip into the bolts for protection?
A) Harnesses
B) Carabiners
C) Quickdraws
D) Ropes

Sport climbing is considered safer than traditional climbing because:
A) It requires no climbing protection
B) It is performed without a belayer
C) It uses pre-drilled permanently fixed bolts
D) The lead climber uses temporary protection equipment

Which of the following is NOT a discipline within competition climbing?
A) Lead climbing
B) Bouldering
C) Speed climbing
D) Aid climbing
